info.description:
# Using Gryzzly APIs

The Web API is a collection of HTTP RPC-style methods, all with URLs in the form `POST http://api.gryzzly.io/v1/RESSOURCE.ACTION`

While it's not a REST API, those familiar with REST should be at home with its foundations in HTTP.

## Building a request

When sending a request to the API:

* you must set the `Content-Type` header to `application/json`
* you must have an `Authorization` header with your API key
* you must set a payload even if empty 
* you may explicitly set the properties of an object to `null` to require its default value

For example, a request to `projects.create` might look like this:

```http
POST /v1/projects.create
Content-type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

{"name":"my project"}
```

and `users.list` might look like this:

```http
POST /v1/users.list
Content-type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

{}
```

## Evaluating responses

A response from the API comes with a JSON object and an HTTP status code.

Successful requests are answered with the status 200 and returned the ressource:

```http
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{}
```

Failed requests are answered with a status 4xx or 5xx and returned an error:

```http
HTTP/1.1 401 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "error_type": "unauthorized_access",
    "error_description": "invalid api key"
}
```

The error object is composed of:

- an `error_type` containing a short machine-readable error code
- an optional `error_description` containing additional information on the error

## Authentication

The API only accepts requests made over HTTPS and requires an `Authorization` header set with an API key.

You can create and manage your API keys from [Gryzzly's Dashboard](https://app.gryzzly.io/administration/api-keys).

The syntax of the `Authorization` header follows the [RFC6750](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6750#section-2.1). It requires the `Bearer` authentification scheme followed by the API key:

```
Authorization: Bearer xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
```

## Rate limits

Gryzzly APIs rely on rate limits to help provide a pleasant experience. We limit our teams to 50 requests per 10 seconds, allowing short burst as well as regular stream.

If you exceed the rate limit, the response will look like this:

```http
HTTP/1.1 429 Too Many Requests
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "error_type": "rate_limits",
    "error_description": "allowed 50 requests per 10 seconds"
}
```
info.title: Swagger Gryzzly API

post.description: This method will fail if their are declarations associated with the project.

The creation of a task is conditioned by the type of budget you want to use
and its position in the project's hierarchy.

### Project hierarchy

A task can be:

- a root task, if is has no parent and is not a group
- a group task, if `is_group` is true
- a subtask, if `parent_id` is set

For exemple, a project might look like this:

```
My project
|
+--A root task
|
+--A group task
   |
   +---A subtask
```

### Budget type

There are 4 types of budget, each with different requirements.

#### None

If you don't need to follow your budget, this is the way to go. Your task only requires a name, the ID of the project and a start date.

You can add the `planned_duration` property if you want additional information and graphics in the dashboard.

#### Detailed

*Only available with the budget offer.*

The detailed budget allows you to track profits for tasks sold with a fixed budget and a fixed amount of time.

For root task and subtask, it requires 2 of the following properties:
- `planned_duration`, the duration planned
- `budget_amount`, the estimated budget
- `hourly_rate`, the rate at which 1 hour is budgeted

#### Global

*Only available with the budget offer.*

The global budget allows you to track profits for tasks sold with a fixed budget and a dynamic amount of time or a dynamic rate.

The following fields are required when creating a root task:

- `budget_amount`
- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == task`

The following fields are required when creating a group task:

- `budget_amount`
- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor | group`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == group`

The following fields are required when creating a subtask:

- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor | group`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == task`

Additional rules apply to the `hourly_rate_mode` in a subtask:

- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `contributor`, it must be set to `contributor`
- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `group`, it must be set to `group`
- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `task`, it can either be `task` or `contributor`

#### Time

*Only available with the budget offer.*

The time budget allows you to track profits for tasks sold with a dynamic budget.

The following fields are required when creating a root task:

- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == task`

The following fields are required when creating a group task:

- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor | group`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == group`

The following fields are required when creating a subtask:

- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor | group`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == task`

Additional rules apply to the `hourly_rate_mode` in a subtask:

- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `contributor`, it must be set to `contributor`
- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `group`, it must be set to `group`
- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `task`, it can either be `task` or `contributor`
This method will fail if their are declarations associated with the task.

The update of a task is conditioned by the type of budget you want to use and its position in the project's hierarchy. You can consult the documentation on how to create a task for detailed information.

### Budget type

There are 4 types of budget, each with different requirements.

#### None

No additional field is required. But you can add the `planned_duration` property if you want additional information and graphics in the dashboard.

### Detailed

For root task and subtask, it requires 2 of the following properties:
- `planned_duration`, the duration planned
- `budget_amount`, the estimated budget
- `hourly_rate`, the rate at which 1 hour is budgeted

#### Global

*Only available with the budget offer.*

The following fields are required when creating a root task:

- `budget_amount`
- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == task`

The following fields are required when creating a group task:

- `budget_amount`
- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor | group`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == group`

The following fields are required when creating a subtask:

- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor | group`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == task`

Additional rules apply to the `hourly_rate_mode` in a subtask:

- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `contributor`, it must be set to `contributor`
- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `group`, it must be set to `group`
- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `task`, it can either be `task` or `contributor`

### Time

*Only available with the budget offer.*

The following fields are required when creating a root task:

- `budget_amount`
- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == task`

The following fields are required when creating a group task:

- `budget_amount`
- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor | group`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == group`

The following fields are required when creating a subtask:

- `hourly_rate_mode: task | contributor | group`
- `hourly_rate` if `hourly_rate_mode == task`

Additional rules apply to the `hourly_rate_mode` in a subtask:

- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `contributor`, it must be set to `contributor`
- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `group`, it must be set to `group`
- if the parent's `hourly_rate_mode` is equal to `task`, it can either be `task` or `contributor`
